summary: This document is an email chain between Assistant U.S. Attorneys in the Southern District of New York discussing two research projects related to the Jeffrey Epstein case. The first project involves locating a government filing that argues the Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement does not prevent prosecution in other federal districts. The second project involves researching case law on whether 18 U.S.C. § 1591 (sex trafficking statute) applied to purchasers (consumers/johns) prior to its 2015 amendment.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the litigation and non-prosecution agreement being discussed. The email chain references litigation against the Southern District of Florida and the scope of the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: Government Sealed Motion to Dismiss Filed
events.description: The government filed a Sealed Motion to Dismiss for Lack of Subject Matter Jurisdiction in litigation related to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Motion Unsealed and Docketed
events.description: The government's Sealed Motion to Dismiss (Document 205-2) was unsealed and docketed.

events.title: Amendment to 18 U.S.C. § 1591
events.description: Congress amended the sex trafficking statute (18 U.S.C. § 1591) to more expressly include defendants who participate in the demand side (purchasers/johns).

keyFacts: The government argued in a 2011 motion that the Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) 'does not bar the United States from bringing federal criminal charges against Epstein for the offenses set forth in the Non-Prosecution Agreement in any other district in this nation.'
A judge recently found that the Southern District of Florida (SDFL) violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act in litigation related to Epstein.

The research project includes analyzing whether the pre-2015 version of 18 U.S.C. § 1591 applied to purchasers (consumers/johns) of commercial sex acts, with cited cases showing conflicting interpretations.
The key case cited for applying § 1591 to consumers is United States v. Jungers (8th Cir. 2013), which held the statute's 'unambiguous text... makes no distinction between suppliers and purchasers.'
A contrary case, Fierro v. Taylor (S.D.N.Y. 2012), held the statute was 'meant to punish those who are the providers or pimps of children, not the purchasers or the johns.'
